awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Trends in Soliton Dynamics and Singularity Formation for Nonlinear Dispersive PDEs
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support the 3-day workshop "Trends in Soliton Dynamics and Singularity Formation for Nonlinear Dispersive PDEs" to be held on the campus of Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas, on October 21-23, 2022. The topic of the workshop lies at the forefront of research on nonlinear wave equations. Wave equations are at the heart of a wide range of natural phenomena, including electromagnetism, fluid dynamics, nonlinear optics, quantum mechanics, general relativity, and particle physics. As such, the rigorous mathematical analysis of these equations is fundamental in obtaining a deeper understanding of the world we live in. This workshop aims to bring together leading international experts and junior researchers, providing an opportunity for the younger generation to interact with leaders of the field and to learn about cutting edge mathematical developments. Junior researchers also can present their research in the form of contributed talks. The workshop is structured to create many opportunities for discussions and to foster an environment for collaboration and for the exchange of ideas.

The mathematical focus of the workshop is on recent developments in the study of soliton dynamics and singularity formation for nonlinear dispersive PDEs, and on the interplay with developments in related areas. In the context of this workshop, solitons refer, roughly speaking, to solutions to partial differential equations that exhibit some form of coherent structure. It is expected that they play an essential role for the overall dynamics. This is an active and fast developing branch of research, where recent ideas and techniques are finding applications in many other areas. The PIs hope this workshop will provide an opportunity for all participants to learn about the fascinating new developments in this area, to form new collaborations, and to explore interesting connections to other areas. Funds will be used for the accommodation and travel costs for junior participants. More information about the workshop and its goals can be found on the website: https://sites.google.com/tamu.edu/solitons-workshop-tamu/about

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Workshop on Trends in Soliton Dynamics and Singularity Formation for Nonlinear Dispersive PDEs took place October 21-23, 2022 on the campus of Texas A&M University. The workshop had 52 registered participants.

Each day of the workshop began with an invited 2-hours mini-course. The mini-courses were delivered by Jacek Jendrej (Université Sorbonne Paris Nord, Title: Soliton resolution for energy-critical equivariant wave maps), Svetlana Roudenko (Florida International University, Title: The world of the KdV-type equations: solitons, stability and blow-up), and Wilhelm Schlag (Yale University, Title: On wave equations with long-range nonlinearities). Invited 50-minutes talks were given by Gong Chen (GeorgiaTech, Title: Dynamics of multi-solitons to Klein-Gordon equations), Andrew Comech (Texas A&M University, Title: Virtual levels and limiting absorption principle), Sung-Jin Oh (UC Berkeley, Title: Codimension one stability of the catenoid under the hyperbolic vanishing mean curvature flow), and Ebru Toprak (Yale University, Title: The effect of threshold energy obstructions on the dispersive estimates for some Schrödinger type equations). Additionally two parallel sessions of overall 15 contributed talks by junior mathematicians were held.

The workshop provided ample opportunities for discussions among the participants and for junior mathematicians to receive feedback on their work from more senior participants. The funds were used to partially support the accommodation and travel costs for participating graduate students and postdocs.
